evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and documented during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as per the hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal scope.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew resists defeaters by addressing alternative causes and confirming consistent evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident in the hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal scope.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The root cause of communication/coordination breakdown among crew fits key features such as miscommunication, lack of clarity, and coordination errors observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident within the hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal scope.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and accessible within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical dynamic under test 3 prefinal dataset.

slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal scope, reflecting typical operational variances.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and documented during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as per the hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal scope.

assumptions: The absence of warnings or challenges from crew members indicates communication breakdown
The documented crew roles and interactions reflect the actual communication dynamics
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew preventing the incident
If procedural deviations rather than communication failures were the primary cause

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 document lack of effective communication and coordination among crew during the pushback, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in interpreting crew interactions and possible procedural deviations

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and accessible within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical dynamic under test 3 prefinal dataset.

assumptions: The historical dynamic under test 3 prefinal dataset includes the cited history items (H1-H13).
Documentation and accessibility imply inclusion of these history records in the dataset.
defeaters: If the dataset lacked explicit documentation of the procedural deviation or if evidence showed mechanical faults causing the event.
If communication breakdown evidence was stronger, indicating lack of procedural adherence was due to coordination failure.

However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H4, H8, H7) documents the procedural deviation in pushback execution and its context, supporting that the deviation is documented and accessible in the dataset. Discriminators favor procedural deviation over communication breakdown, environment deficiency, or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit mention of dataset accessibility or format; assumption that historical dynamic under test 3 prefinal dataset includes these documented events.

node.statement: The root cause of communication/coordination breakdown among crew fits key features such as miscommunication, lack of clarity, and coordination errors observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident within the hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal scope.

assumptions: Miscommunication and lack of warnings among crew constitute communication/coordination breakdown
The absence of warnings and assumptions by crew members indicate coordination errors

If procedural deviations rather than communication failures were the primary cause

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal scope, reflecting typical operational variances.

assumptions: The TRP markings are assumed to be standard and visible as per H7 and H13.
The procedural deviation is interpreted primarily from the pushback exceeding the TRP and the instructor's actions.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the TRP markings were inadequate or not visible, or if environmental factors prevented adherence to procedure, this would change the assessment.
If communication or coordination failures were primary causes, the procedural deviation alignment would be less supported.

The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4, H7, H8, H10, H12, and H13 describe the pushback exceeding the TRP marking and the small size of the TRP, supporting that the procedural deviation aligns with key features of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA pushback scope. The discriminator disc:R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION|R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY favors procedural deviation over environmental deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether environmental marking deficiencies contributed to the deviation

node.statement: The identified procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands potential counterarguments and alternative explanations within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal context, confirming its validity.

Operator statements are accurate and complete regarding control and communication

No additional environmental or marking deficiencies beyond those mentioned influenced the event.

defeaters: If evidence showed that the pushback continued due to procedural deviation or communication breakdown rather than mechanical/control failure, the conclusion would change.
If physical marking or environmental deficiencies were proven to be the primary cause, this would favor the environmental deficiency hypothesis.

The physical presence and visibility of the TRP marking imply availability of the environmental/marking deficiency.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were obscured or not physically present in the environment under test.
If communication or procedural failures were clearly documented as primary causes without environmental marking issues.

Discriminators favor environmental deficiency over procedural deviation or communication breakdown due to physical marking evidence and lack of effective communication signals (H8, H12, H13).
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in the effectiveness of communication signals and procedural adherence; no explicit statement that markings were deficient or missing.

No contradictory evidence about personnel availability present

outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence on personnel availability issues; ambiguity could arise if communication breakdown evidence appeared

The small size of the TRP marking implies a deficiency in environmental marking adequacy.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were missing or obscured, or if the tug driver had clear visual cues and warnings, the fit to key features would be contradicted.
If procedural deviations or communication failures were proven to be the sole cause, the environmental deficiency alignment would be less relevant.

outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the marking size and visibility fully meet the defined key features; limited direct evidence on marking adequacy.

node.statement: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or counterexamples within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical dynamic under test 3 prefinal context.

assumptions: The small size and limited visibility of the TRP marking contributed to the pushback error.
Procedural communication methods were insufficient to compensate for marking deficiencies.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, unambiguous, and adequately visible TRP markings with effective communication signals, this would challenge the environmental deficiency claim.

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure evidence for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 within hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal is robust against potential defeaters and alternative explanations.

assumptions: No hardware fault codes or bench checks contradicting mechanical failure are present in the evidence.
Communication failures are adequately represented by the lack of warnings from wingman and headset operator.
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication and warnings were given but the collision still occurred, this would challenge the mechanical failure explanation.
If hardware fault codes or bench checks indicated no mechanical issues, procedural or communication causes would be favored.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H8, H12) shows communication was ongoing but no warnings were given to prevent the collision, supporting mechanical/control failure over communication breakdown as the cause.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in human factors and possible unreported procedural deviations

node.statement: The marking deficiency was not effectively mitigated by existing detection or monitoring systems

assumptions: The visual signals and monitoring systems referenced are considered part of the existing detection or monitoring systems for marking deficiencies.
The lack of warnings from the wingman and headset operator implies ineffective mitigation by monitoring systems.
defeaters: If there was evidence that the visual signals or monitoring systems were adequate and were properly used but the incident still occurred, that would change the assessment.
If the crew had received timely and effective warnings from the headset operator or wingman that were ignored, it would suggest procedural failure rather than marking deficiency.

The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 and H12 indicate that existing visual signals and monitoring by crew were insufficient to prevent the aircraft moving beyond the TRP and hitting the blast fence, supporting that marking deficiency was not effectively mitigated. H13 notes the small size of the TRP and lack of mandatory use of marshalling wands, further supporting marking inadequacy.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether procedural non-compliance or communication failures contributed more significantly than marking deficiency

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically present and accessible during the event
children_spec.test_procedure: Check crew attendance logs, cockpit voice recordings, and witness statements to confirm presence and accessibility

children_spec.statement: Communication equipment was operational and available to the crew
children_spec.test_procedure: Review maintenance records and equipment status reports; analyze cockpit voice recorder for communication device functionality

children_spec.statement: Relevant information was available and accessible to the crew when needed
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine flight data, manuals, and information systems to verify availability and accessibility of necessary information

node.statement: Availability of required pushback equipment at the time of operation

assumptions: Qualified personnel imply availability of required pushback equipment
No mention of equipment faults suggests equipment was functional
defeaters: If evidence showed equipment was missing or malfunctioning
If communication breakdown was proven to be primary cause
If environmental markings were inadequate causing confusion

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1-H4, H8-H10, H12) directly supports that required pushback equipment was available and operated by qualified personnel, indicating procedural deviation rather than equipment unavailability.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct statement about equipment availability but inferred from roles and actions; some ambiguity in communication effectiveness.

node.statement: Communication equipment was operational and available to the crew

assumptions: Communication equipment availability implies operational status
No hardware faults reported implies mechanical systems were functional
defeaters: If evidence showed communication equipment was non-functional or unavailable
If warnings or alerts were received and ignored

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H3, H8, H12) shows communication equipment was operational and available, but coordination breakdown occurred due to insufficient signals and lack of warnings, contradicting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew interactions and signal effectiveness

node.statement: Relevant information was available and accessible to the crew when needed

assumptions: Assuming that the absence of warnings from wingman and headset operator implies lack of accessible relevant information.
Assuming that the trainee driver's silence indicates a communication breakdown rather than a procedural choice.
defeaters: If there was evidence that the crew received timely and clear warnings about the TRP and acted accordingly, or if the communication channels were proven effective.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 indicate that relevant information was not effectively communicated or acted upon by the crew, contradicting the claim that information was available and accessible when needed.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew communication effectiveness and possible unreported verbal exchanges

children_spec.statement: Mechanical/control failure is resistant to immediate detection by onboard monitoring systems
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze onboard monitoring system logs and failure detection alerts to determine if the failure was detected promptly

children_spec.statement: Mechanical/control failure is resistant to manual override or pilot intervention
children_spec.test_procedure: Test pilot ability to override or control the system manually during failure scenarios in simulations or incident reports

children_spec.statement: Mechanical/control failure is resistant to automatic safety system interventions
children_spec.test_procedure: Evaluate automatic safety system responses and their effectiveness in mitigating the failure in flight data and simulations

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure is resistant to manual override or pilot intervention

defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical controls were unresponsive to manual override or pilot intervention during the pushback.

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 and H12 indicate the tug instructor was in control and the pushback continued past the TRP without warnings or intervention, suggesting procedural deviation rather than mechanical/control failure resistant to manual override.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the continued movement was due to mechanical failure or procedural error.

node.statement: Availability of clear communication channels between ground crew and flight deck during pushback

assumptions: Communication via interphone and headset operator implies availability of clear communication channels.
Lack of warnings from wingman or headset operator indicates communication was not effectively used, not unavailable.
defeaters: If evidence showed that communication channels were not established or were non-functional during pushback.
If visual or verbal warnings were effectively given and ignored, indicating communication failure rather than procedural deviation.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H8, H11, and H12 show that communication channels existed between ground crew and flight deck, but visual signals were insufficient and no warnings were given, supporting availability of communication channels during pushback.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in effectiveness of communication despite availability

node.statement: Personnel responsible for identifying marking deficiencies were not able to detect or report the deficiency due to procedural or training limitations

defeaters: If evidence showed personnel lacked training or procedural guidance on TRP markings or if communication methods were adequate but ignored, the claim might be supported.

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.
The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H8, H9, H11, H12, H13) shows personnel were trained and aware of TRP markings and procedures, but communication and signaling limitations contributed to the failure to stop, contradicting the claim that personnel were unable to detect or report the deficiency due to procedural or training limitations.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether visual signaling methods were sufficient or if personnel attentiveness was a factor

node.statement: Crew members were physically present and accessible during the event

defeaters: If evidence showed crew members were absent or inaccessible during the event, or communication was impossible, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3, H8, H11-H13 directly confirm that crew members were physically present and accessible during the event, supporting the claim and favoring communication breakdown over procedural deviation as per discriminator disc:R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION|R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; evidence clearly indicates physical presence and accessibility.

children_spec.statement: Crew members were not reachable or did not respond during critical phases
children_spec.test_procedure: Check communication logs and recordings for missed or unanswered calls or messages during the incident timeframe

children_spec.statement: Communication equipment was unavailable or malfunctioning
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect maintenance records and equipment status reports for failures or outages of communication devices

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically separated or isolated preventing timely communication
children_spec.test_procedure: Review crew positioning and movement logs or testimonies to verify physical availability for communication

children_spec.statement: Pushback crew was available and present at the scheduled time
children_spec.test_procedure: Check crew attendance records and timestamps to confirm presence at scheduled pushback time

children_spec.statement: Pushback equipment was operational and ready for use
children_spec.test_procedure: Review maintenance logs and equipment status reports to verify operational readiness

children_spec.statement: Communication systems between pushback crew and cockpit were functional
children_spec.test_procedure: Test communication logs and equipment functionality to confirm effective communication

node.statement: Crew members were not reachable or did not respond during critical phases

assumptions: The absence of warnings or responses from crew members implies they were not reachable or did not respond during critical phases.
defeaters: If evidence showed active, timely communication or warnings from crew members during the critical phases, or if the crew were reachable and responsive.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 directly indicate that crew members (wingman, headset operator, trainee driver) did not warn or respond to the tug instructor during the critical pushback phase, supporting the claim of communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the lack of warnings was due to unreachability or conscious choice not to intervene

node.statement: Pushback equipment was operational and ready for use

assumptions: Operational status of pushback equipment inferred from active use and control by instructor
No reported equipment faults implies equipment was ready and functional
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical faults or equipment malfunction preventing proper operation
If environmental factors or marking deficiencies were proven to cause the incident
If communication breakdown was documented as primary cause

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H2, H3, H8, H12) shows the tug equipment was operational and the instructor actively controlled the pushback, indicating availability and readiness of pushback equipment, supporting the claim. Discriminators favor procedural deviation over communication breakdown or equipment failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct mechanical fault evidence; some ambiguity in communication signals and operator actions

node.statement: Pushback crew was available and present at the scheduled time

defeaters: If evidence showed the crew was absent or delayed at the scheduled time
If communication logs indicated no crew presence or availability

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.
The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback.
The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman.
He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3, H9-H12 directly describe the presence and availability of the pushback crew at the scheduled time, supporting the claim that the pushback crew was available and present.
outcome.uncertainty_source: none

node.statement: Communication systems between pushback crew and cockpit were functional

assumptions: Interphone communication between flight crew and headset operator implies functional communication systems.
Qualified personnel imply operational communication capability.
defeaters: If evidence showed communication equipment malfunction or lack of communication attempts between crew members.
If the headset operator or wingman had not been qualified or aware of procedures.
If there were reports of communication breakdown or failure to relay critical warnings.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H8, H11, and H12 indicate that communication systems between pushback crew and cockpit were functional, with the flight crew communicating via interphone and the headset operator and wingman qualified and aware of procedures, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct mention of communication system failures, but some ambiguity about effectiveness of visual signals and situational awareness.

node.statement: Communication equipment was unavailable or malfunctioning

assumptions: Communication equipment was functioning as no direct evidence of malfunction is reported.
Communication breakdown refers to coordination failures despite equipment availability.
defeaters: If evidence showed hardware faults or communication equipment malfunctioning, or explicit reports of equipment unavailability, this would change the conclusion.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 and H12 indicate no hardware malfunction but communication lapses among crew, supporting communication equipment was available but coordination failed, favoring communication breakdown over mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether communication equipment functioned fully or if human factors caused breakdown

node.statement: Crew members were physically separated or isolated preventing timely communication

defeaters: If evidence showed physical separation or isolation preventing communication
If communication devices failed or were unavailable
If crew members reported inability to communicate timely

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H8, H10, H12) shows crew members were seated together and in communication, with no indication of physical separation or isolation preventing timely communication, contradicting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are present and visible at the accident site
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the accident site for presence and visibility of all required environmental markings; absence or poor visibility lowers probability

children_spec.statement: Environmental markings are maintained and not obscured by weather or other factors
children_spec.test_procedure: Evaluate weather conditions and site maintenance records to determine if markings were obscured or degraded at the time; evidence of obscuration lowers probability

children_spec.statement: Environmental markings are correctly located according to regulatory standards
children_spec.test_procedure: Compare marking locations with regulatory standards and site plans; discrepancies reduce probability

children_spec.statement: Pushback team members were present and available at the scheduled time
children_spec.test_procedure: Check personnel attendance records and timestamps to verify if all required pushback team members were present and ready at the scheduled pushback time

children_spec.statement: Pushback equipment was operational and accessible during the pushback procedure
children_spec.test_procedure: Review maintenance logs and equipment status reports to confirm that pushback tugs and related equipment were functional and available at the time of pushback

children_spec.statement: Communication channels between pushback team and flight crew were open and functioning
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze communication logs and recordings to verify that communication devices were operational and messages were exchanged without interruption during pushback
